Key Arguments: The definition of 'misinformation' is unclear and subjective.
Past instances of information labeled as 'misinformation' were later proven true or plausible, such as the Wuhan lab leak theory.
Censorship of dissenting views during the COVID-19 pandemic was often influenced by government pressure on Big Tech.
Censorship is contrary to the principle of free speech, which is fundamental to democracies.
The bill excludes government and mainstream media, which have also spread misinformation.
The bill is perceived as a tool for the government to silence critics.
Notable Quotes: Is ACMA aware that a lot of what was defined by governments, the mainstream media and 'fact checkers' as 'misinformation' early in the covid pandemic, is now accepted to have in fact been true, and or plausible?
The use of censorship to control it is anathema to the principle of free speech, which I thought was fundamental to democracies in the West.
This 'misinformation bill' seems to be a thinly disguised attempt by the government to silence and punish its critics.
